description:
Pogoniulus pusillus, also known as the Red-fronted Tinkerbird or Tiny Tinkerbird, is a species of bird in the family Lybiidae. It is a small, brightly colored bird found in sub-Saharan Africa.

The Red-fronted Tinkerbird has a distinctive appearance, with a red forehead, yellow supercilium (eyebrow), and black and white plumage. It is one of the smallest members of the tinkerbird family, measuring around 9-10 cm in length. The species is known for its distinctive "tink-tink-tink" call, which is the source of its common name.

Habitat-wise, the Red-fronted Tinkerbird is typically found in various types of woodland and forest habitats, including moist and dry forests, as well as more open wooded areas. It feeds primarily on small fruits, berries, and insects, foraging both in the canopy and lower vegetation.

This species is considered to be of Least Concern on the IUCN Red List, with a stable population and a wide distribution across sub-Saharan Africa. It is an important part of the local ecosystem, contributing to seed dispersal and insect control through its feeding habits.
